text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, from West 58th (left) to 59th (right) Street's, showing the Plaza Hotel, opened to the public in 1890. It is set back from the Avenue with a small plaza and has Central Park on its north (right). Demolished in 1907, it was replaced with a new hotel structure of the same name.
Neg.#1496

slide # 39        1890's

Langill, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Streets.
This hotel was later razed (1907) and the present Hotel Plaza
erected on its site.
1894.

Fifth Avenue, west side, south from 58th Street, showing Vanderbilt
Chateau, demolished in 1927.
This was the residence of Cornelius Vanderbilt, and was famous
for its ballroom.
June 1925.

58th Street, north side, from Fifth to Madison Avenues. At the left is the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, and at the right is The Madison,
an apartment house.
August 15, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

58th Street at N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue, showing the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, seen from the Heckscher Building on the S.W. corner across
excavation on S.E. corner.
Auguat 15, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

Fifth Ave., west side, between West 58th and West 59th Streets, showing prominently, the Pulitzer Memorial Fountain at, the S.W. corner of West 59th Street. The fountain was erected from funds left by Joseph Pulitzer, and is constructed of limestone and consists of six basins rising in pyramidal form. In the center of the top basin, on a pedestal, is a bronze statue, eight feet high, of a nude female figure holding a basket of fruit. The fountain is often called the Fountain of Abundance. The sculptor is Carl Bittner, who lived from 1865 to 1915 and the architects
are Carrere and Hastings. It was given to the city in 1916.
August 15, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

South on Fifth Avenue from Sherry-Netherlands Tower at 58th Street,
showing Heckscher Building in foreground.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Fifth Avenue, east side, at East 58th Street (center), showing north of that point the Savoy-Plaza Hotel (left) and south of same, the Squibb Building (right). This view is photographed in a south easterlv direction from 59th Street and across a portion of the Grand Arm Plaza, the latter occuping the west side of the Avenue, between 59th and 58th Streets. Partially shown on the extreme right is the
Plaza Hotel.
About 1936
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.5.

Central Park: a view across the southeastern corner of the Park, showing prominently buildings on the east side of Fifth Avenue, between East 60th and 58th Streets. From left to right, these are, the Squibb Building, the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, the Sherry Netherland Hotel and the Ritm Tower. The latter
is at the N.E. corner of Park Avenue and East 57th Street.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.B.

Central Park: A view southeastward across the Boat Lake, showing buildings on the east side of Fifth Avene, south from East 60th (left) to 58th (right) Streets. Prominent of these are, the Sherry Netherland, the Savoy-Plasa,
and the Squibb Building.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

Fifth Ave., at 58th Street, showing the Puliter Memorial Fountain. located on the west side of the Ave., between 59th and 58th Streets. This area is known as the Grand Army Plaza. IIt was erected in 1915 to the memory of Joseph Pulitzer, foraer owner of the New York World, and was sculptured by arl Bitter. The fountain is surmounted by a bronze female figure symbolizing Abundance,. bearing a basket laden with the fruits of the earth. It is often referred to as the Fountain of Abundance. At the extreme left appears a portion of the Satoy-Plaza Hotel, at the N.E. corner of East 58th Street, and (center) a portion of the Squibbs Building, at the S.E. corner of the latter street.
.  1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Fifth Ave., west side, between West 58th (left) and 59th (right) Streets, showing the Pulitzer Memorial Fountain on the Plaza. It was erected in 1915 to the memory of Joseph Pulitzer, former proprietor of the New York World, and was sculptured by Earl Bitter. It is often referred to as the Fountain of Abundance. On the right appears a portion
of the Hotel Plaza, which faces the Plasa.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
